Mark Baker wrote:

>[...]
>I can't tell you why it's not getting through.  Part of it for a lot
>of people is certainly "mob mentality"; that there's comfort in knowing
>that the person beside you believes the same thing.  There's also the
>issue that mental models are hard to change, and getting this point for
>many people requires a new one.  Combined, they're nasty.
>  
>
I think you hit the nail on the head there - mental models are hard to 
change.  People are used to RPC for network-based applications, and SOAP 
provides exactly that.  That and the fact that you've taken something 
they're familiar with and sprinkled it with the magic pixie dust that is 
the web and XML; how can it not be the ultimate application platform? :-/

Seriously, though, I expect that a lot of people just don't see the 
relevance of your arguments because they have the wrong mental model.   
 When you're doing RPC, it isn't clear that caching RPC messages has 
much benefit.

--Chuck
